questions.question: What does the best bid in an order book represent?

options.text: The lowest price someone is willing to sell at
The highest price someone is willing to buy at
The average price of all bids

questions.question: What is the bid-ask spread?

options.text: The difference between the highest bid and lowest ask
The total volume available in the order book
The difference between open and close prices
The gap between two consecutive trades

questions.question: Which order type guarantees execution but not price?
What happens when a buy limit order is placed above the current best ask?

options.text: It is rejected by the exchange
It rests in the order book unchanged
It executes immediately against available sell orders
It becomes a market order automatically

questions.question: What is a trade?

options.text: An order submitted to an exchange
A matched buy and sell resulting in execution
A change in the best bid or ask
The total volume in the order book

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a quote?

options.text: The best bid and best ask at a point in time

questions.question: Why are timestamps critical in market data?

options.text: They allow correct sequencing and joining of events

questions.question: If you want to attach the most recent quote to each trade, what kind of join logic is typically required?

options.text: An exact equality join on timestamp
A join to the nearest future quote
A join to the most recent prior quote

questions.question: What does order book depth refer to?

options.text: The number of trades executed in a day
The total number of orders ever submitted
The volume available at multiple price levels
The spread between bid and ask

questions.question: Why might a trade occur at a price outside the current quoted bid-ask spread?

options.text: Because the quote data is always wrong
Due to latency, hidden liquidity, or reporting delays
Because market orders ignore prices entirely
Because spreads only apply to limit orders

questions.question: Which of the following can cause the displayed best bid or ask to change?

options.text: A new order improving the price
A cancellation of the current best order
A trade executing at a worse price level
A change in the company’s fundamentals

questions.question: Which characteristics typically apply to limit orders?

options.text: They specify a maximum or minimum execution price
They may not execute at all

questions.question: What information is commonly found in a trade record?

options.text: Full depth of the order book

questions.question: Which statements about market orders are generally true?

options.text: They always execute at the mid-price
They add liquidity to the book

questions.question: Which of the following can be inferred directly from quotes but not from trades alone?

options.text: Available liquidity at the best prices

questions.question: What does it mean if an order book is described as ‘deep’?

options.text: Large volumes are available across many price levels
Large trades can be absorbed with limited price impact

questions.question: Which events reduce visible liquidity in an order book?

options.text: New limit orders away from the market

questions.question: Why might multiple trades share the same timestamp?

options.text: They were part of a single large order execution
Quotes and trades are identical data

questions.question: Which statements about bid and ask sizes are correct?

options.text: They represent available quantity at that price
They can change without a price change
They always equal the last trade size
They only change when trades occur

questions.question: Which issues commonly arise when joining trades to quotes?
What does it mean to ‘remove liquidity’?

options.text: Executing against existing orders in the book
Placing a limit order inside the spread
Reducing available size at a price level
Widening the bid-ask spread by default

questions.question: Which of the following are valid reasons for partial fills?

options.text: Insufficient quantity at the desired price
The order was a market order
The exchange enforces minimum trade sizes

questions.question: Which data fields are useful for reconstructing an order book?
Which statements about spreads are generally true?

options.text: They tend to widen during volatile periods
They are a cost paid by aggressive traders
They are fixed throughout the trading day

questions.question: What can cause two venues to show different best prices for the same instrument?
Which statements about trade direction inference are correct?

options.text: It often relies on comparing trade price to quotes
It is always explicitly provided by exchanges

questions.question: What does a crossed market indicate?

options.text: Best bid is higher than best ask
A temporary data or latency issue

questions.question: Which of the following are common sanity checks on quote data?

options.text: Bid price is less than ask price

questions.question: Why might trades appear without any nearby quote updates?

options.text: Quote data was filtered or sampled
Trades do not affect the market
Trades bypass the order book entirely

questions.question: Which factors influence execution price for a market order?
What does time priority mean in most order books?

options.text: Earlier orders at the same price execute first

questions.question: Which of the following can legitimately change without a trade occurring?
Why is exact timestamp equality often avoided when joining market data?

options.text: Events rarely occur at identical times

questions.question: Which properties are typical of exchange-traded order books?
What does slippage refer to?

options.text: Execution at a worse price than expected

questions.question: Which of the following are reasons to aggregate market data?
What information is lost when aggregating trades into bars?
Which statements about liquidity are correct?

options.text: It can vary significantly over time
It is constant during market hours

questions.question: What does it mean if a quote is described as ‘stale’?

options.text: It no longer reflects current market conditions
It has been superseded by newer information
It was generated outside trading hours

questions.question: Which challenges are specific to high-frequency market data?
Which of the following actions typically add liquidity to an order book?

options.text: Placing a limit order away from the best price
Placing a limit order that does not immediately execute

questions.question: What information is required to uniquely identify a trade?

options.text: Execution timestamp or unique trade ID
Best bid and ask at the time

questions.question: Which statements about tick size are correct?

options.text: It defines the minimum price increment
It can influence the bid-ask spread
It is always the same across instruments
It has no impact on market liquidity

questions.question: Why might two consecutive quote updates have identical prices?

options.text: An order was cancelled and replaced at the same price

questions.question: Which of the following can cause market impact?

options.text: High liquidity at many price levels

questions.question: Which properties distinguish quotes from trades?

options.text: Quotes reflect intentions, trades reflect executions
Quotes can exist without trades occurring
Trades always include bid and ask prices

questions.question: Which situations can lead to wide bid-ask spreads?

options.text: High trading volume with deep books

questions.question: What does a quote update with zero size typically indicate?

options.text: A cancellation of all orders at that price
A trade executed at that price

questions.question: Which statements about volume-weighted average price (VWAP) are correct?

options.text: It weights prices by traded volume
It can be computed from trade data
It requires full order book depth

questions.question: Why might trade prices cluster at certain levels?
Which of the following are consequences of low market liquidity?
Which events can trigger quote updates without any trade?
Which data attributes are commonly shared by both trades and quotes?
What does it mean when liquidity is said to be ‘fragmented’?

options.text: Orders are spread across multiple venues
No single book shows the full market

questions.question: Which statements about market depth snapshots are correct?

options.text: They represent the book at a specific point in time

questions.question: Why might a trade not change the best bid or ask?

options.text: It executed at a deeper price level
There was sufficient size remaining at the best price

questions.question: Which of the following are challenges when aggregating data across venues?
What does it mean for an order to be ‘hidden’?

options.text: It does not appear in the public order book
It may still interact with visible orders
It always executes at the mid-price

questions.question: Which of the following describe trade-throughs?

options.text: Executing at a worse price than available elsewhere

questions.question: Which of the following are valid uses of mid-price?
Which situations can lead to out-of-order market data?
What does it mean if a quote is ‘locked’?

options.text: It may precede a crossed market

questions.question: Which factors affect the quality of a quote?
Why might multiple trades occur at the same price but different sizes?

options.text: They match against different resting orders
A large order was split across executions
Prices are random within a tick

questions.question: Which of the following are common data quality checks on trades?
What does price-time priority imply for traders?

options.text: Better prices execute before worse prices
Earlier orders at the same price have an advantage

questions.question: Which of the following can indicate poor market data quality?
Why are joins between trades and quotes often many-to-one?

options.text: Multiple trades can occur between quote updates
Quotes are updated less frequently than trades
Each trade generates a new quote
Quotes and trades share unique IDs

questions.question: Which statements about pre-trade and post-trade data are correct?
What does it mean if liquidity ‘dries up’?
Which factors can cause the mid-price to change?

options.text: A change in the best bid
A change in the best ask
A cancellation away from the best prices

questions.question: Which statements about aggressive orders are correct?

options.text: They immediately interact with existing liquidity
They tend to pay the bid-ask spread

questions.question: Which properties are typical of passive orders?

options.text: They rest in the order book if not executed

questions.question: Why might a limit order not execute even if the market trades at that price?

options.text: Time priority placed other orders ahead of it
Limit orders cannot execute at their own price

questions.question: Which of the following can affect observed spreads across time?

options.text: The accounting period of the firm

questions.question: Which data issues can distort trade-price analysis?
What does it mean when liquidity is said to be ‘thin’?

options.text: Small available size at each price level
Large trades cause larger price moves
Trading volume is guaranteed to be low

questions.question: Which of the following can cause apparent price jumps in trade data?

options.text: Trades executing across multiple price levels

questions.question: Which statements about quote frequency are correct?

options.text: Quotes can update more frequently than trades
High quote frequency can increase data volume

questions.question: Which scenarios can produce identical consecutive trades?

options.text: Repeated executions at the same price and size

questions.question: Which statements about order cancellations are correct?

options.text: They can occur without any trade
They always change the best price

questions.question: Which of the following are reasons to analyse order book imbalance?
Which data characteristics make joining market data harder?
What does it mean if trades consistently execute at the ask?

options.text: Liquidity is being removed on the sell side

questions.question: Which of the following describe the inside market?

options.text: Best bid and best ask prices
Prices most likely to trade next

questions.question: Which outcomes can result from a large market order?

options.text: Guaranteed full fill at best price

questions.question: Which statements about exchange timestamps are correct?

options.text: They may differ from local receipt times
They are essential for event ordering
They are always unique per event

questions.question: Which of the following can cause misleading VWAP calculations?
Why might order book depth appear to vanish suddenly?
Which properties are typical of auction periods?
Which statements about price impact are correct?

options.text: It is higher in illiquid markets
It is independent of market depth

questions.question: Which of the following can cause trade prices to lag quote prices?
What does it mean when liquidity providers ‘step back’?

options.text: They cancel or widen their quotes

questions.question: Which statements about trade size distributions are correct?

options.text: Many small trades can coexist with few large ones
They are normally distributed by rule

questions.question: Which effects can auctions have on observed prices?

options.text: Concentration of volume at a single price

questions.question: Which of the following can distort apparent liquidity measures?
Why is symbol normalisation important when joining data?

options.text: Different venues may use different identifiers

questions.question: Which statements about last-trade price are correct?

options.text: It reflects the most recent execution
It may be stale during quiet periods

questions.question: Which of the following are reasons to use rolling time windows in analysis?
Which conditions can lead to misleading conclusions from raw trade data?

options.text: Failing to account for liquidity changes
